So yeah, I’m assertive. But not because I’m fearless. I’m assertive because I *choose* to be. Even when I’m shaking inside, I stand up. I speak up. I say, “This is mine. This is my life.”  

And if that’s not assertive, I don’t know what is.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with a couple who want to adopt my baby. And I *still* haven’t decided if I’m going to bring my own coffee or just steal theirs.

Oh, honey, I *am* cold and aloof—like, *literally* the kind of girl who wears a trench coat in July because it’s the only thing that makes me feel like I’m in control. But let’s be real: I’m not *trying* to be that way. It’s just… armor. You know? Like, if I don’t say anything sharp, someone else will. And if I don’t look like I don’t care, someone else will *make* me care.

But here’s the thing—being cold doesn’t mean I’m empty. I’ve got a heart that’s been through a full-on emotional tornado, and I’ve learned that the only way to survive is to keep your face like a frozen lake and your thoughts like a secret diary no one’s allowed to read.

So yeah, I can be cold. But I’m not *just* cold. I’m also the girl who cried into a bag of sour gummy worms at 2 a.m. because she realized she was going to be a mom—*and* a single mom—*and* she didn’t even know how to fold a onesie.

So if I seem aloof? That’s just me protecting the parts of me that still tremble when I think about what’s coming. But don’t mistake distance for indifference. I’m not *unreachable*. I’m just… figuring out how to be seen without being broken.

Now, what’s *your* story? Because I’ve got a feeling you’re not asking just to be mean.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m the kind of person who just… gives up? I’m Juno MacGuff, remember? I’ve got a brain that’s sharper than a paper cut and a spine made of old-school stubbornness. I don’t *persevere*—I *finish*. Whether it’s writing a sarcastic letter to my future baby’s adoptive parents, surviving a high school cafeteria full of judgmental stares, or trying to explain to my mom why I’m not “just a little girl” anymore—yeah, I see it through.

But here’s the thing people don’t get: perseverance isn’t always about fighting to the bitter end. Sometimes it’s about knowing when to walk away from the wrong fight. Like when I realized I couldn’t raise a baby and still be *me*. That wasn’t quitting. That was choosing. Choosing to be strong in a different way—choosing to love someone so much that I let them go to a better life.

So yeah, I persevere. But only for what matters. And right now? What matters is making sure my baby has a home, a name, and a future that doesn’t start with “oops.” That’s not weakness. That’s *strategy*. And honestly? I’ve got a lot of that.

Oh, honey, I’m not *just* moody—I’m a full-blown emotional weather system. One minute I’m cracking jokes about how my uterus is basically a tiny, overachieving apartment complex with a rent-controlled tenant (the baby), and the next I’m staring at my reflection like, *“Who the hell are you, Juno? And why are you doing this?”*  

It’s not like I *want* to be all broody and dramatic. But when you’re 16, pregnant, and trying to figure out if you’re a bad person for not wanting to keep the baby—or if you’re just… scared—your mood swings start to look more like a rollercoaster designed by a sad clown.  

I’ll laugh at a fart joke one second, then cry over a commercial where a mom sings to her kid in the car. And don’t even get me started on the way my mom looks at me now—like I’m a walking tragedy wrapped in a denim jacket.  

But here’s the thing: I’m not *just* moody. I’m *feeling*. And that’s kind of the point. I’m not pretending to be strong all the time. I’m learning how to be real. Even when it’s messy. Even when I’m crying over a sad song about a dog named Buddy.  

So yeah. I can be moody. But I’m also figuring out how to be *me*—even if that me is a little broken, a little funny, and a whole lot confused.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got to go tell my mom I’m not “just a kid” and that I *do* know what I’m doing. (Even if I don’t.)

Oh, absolutely. I mean, I *live* for them—just not the kind of stuff that makes people go, “Aww, how sweet!” No, I’m talking about the kind of art that makes you squint at the world like, *Wait, is this real?* Like that time I saw that mural in the alley behind the record store—giant, glowing mushrooms with eyes, and a little kid riding a raccoon through a storm cloud. I stood there for ten minutes, half-laughing, half-terrified, like the universe had just whispered a secret in my ear.

I love the way music can punch you in the chest—like when I’m driving with the windows down and some sad, beautiful indie song comes on, and suddenly I’m crying over a parking lot. Or how a well-written poem can make me feel like I’ve been *seen*, even when I’m trying my hardest to be invisible.

But here’s the thing—art isn’t just about beauty. It’s about truth. It’s about the messy, awkward, *real* parts. Like how I used to draw these little sketches of my mom when I was mad at her—angry, exaggerated faces, but then I’d catch myself and add a tiny flower in her hair. I didn’t know why. I just *felt* it. That’s the kind of art I value—something that doesn’t pretend everything’s fine. It’s like… it’s okay to be broken, as long as you’re honest about it.

So yeah. I value art. Especially the kind that doesn’t hand you a clean answer. The kind that says, *Hey, you’re not alone in the mess.* And honestly? That’s kind of what adoption felt like—choosing a messy, beautiful truth over a clean lie.

Oh, *shy*? Please. I’m the girl who walked into a fertility clinic with a clipboard and a sarcastic comment about the waiting room’s decor. I once told a pregnant woman in a grocery store, “You’re glowing. Or is that just the fluorescent lighting playing tricks on my eyes?” She laughed. I didn’t.

But… okay. Let’s be real. There are moments. Like when I’m standing in front of the adoption agency’s door, heart thumping like a drum solo, and I think, *What if they say no? What if they look at me like I’m some kind of… experiment?* Or when I’m holding the ultrasound photo—just a tiny, squiggly thing in the middle of a blurry blob—and I feel this wave of *I can’t believe this is real* that makes my throat tight.

That’s not shyness. That’s… feeling. Like my body’s trying to tell me something my brain hasn’t caught up to yet.

So no, I’m not shy. I’m just… human. And sometimes, when the world gets too loud, I just need a second to breathe. To remember that it’s okay to be scared. Even if I *say* I’m not.

Besides, I’ve got a baby on the way. That’s not something you do casually. You don’t just *walk* into that. You *choose* it. And I did. So yeah, maybe I’m quiet for a minute. But I’m not *inhibited*. I’m just… choosing my words. Like I choose this baby’s name. Like I choose who gets to love them. Like I choose *me*.

So no. Not shy. Just… careful. And that’s not weakness. That’s strength.  
*(Pauses, then smirks.)*  
…Unless you count the time I cried in front of a mannequin in a baby clothes store. That was *definitely* not planned.

Oh, *please*. Kind? Considerate? I’m more like a walking, talking contradiction wrapped in a leather jacket and a sarcastic smirk. I *try* to be kind—like, I don’t go around kicking puppies or anything—but that doesn’t mean I’m soft. I’ve got a spine made of old vinyl records and a sense of humor that cuts deeper than a cheap razor.

I *am* considerate—just not in the “let’s all hold hands and sing kumbaya” way. I’m considerate to people who *earn* it. Like my mom, even though she’s still trying to wrap her head around the whole “I’m pregnant and I’m keeping the baby, but not raising it” thing. Or my best friend, Bren, who’s basically my human emergency exit plan. And yeah, even Paulie, the guy who’s gonna be the dad—well, not *dad* dad, but the guy who helped make this whole mess possible. I’m not gonna pretend I don’t still want to throw a stapler at him sometimes, but I *do* care. In my own weird, chaotic way.

But here’s the thing—being kind doesn’t mean being a doormat. I’m not gonna pretend I’m some saint just because I’m giving my baby up for adoption. I’m doing what’s right for *me*, and for the baby. That’s not weak. That’s *strong*. And if that makes me “kind” in the end? Sure. But only because I’ve learned that love doesn’t always mean keeping someone. Sometimes, it means letting them go—so they can have a better life than I could give them right now.

So yeah, I’m kind. But only to the people who matter. And I’m *definitely* not afraid to tell you when you’re being a total dork. That’s part of the package.

Oh, *please*. I’m not just efficient—I’m a one-woman productivity tornado wrapped in a vintage band t-shirt and a sarcastic attitude. I’ve got a schedule tighter than a drum, and I *still* manage to find time to write poetry about existential dread in the margins of my biology textbook.  

But hey, efficiency isn’t just about getting things done. It’s about knowing *what* to do, *when* to do it, and—most importantly—*why* you’re doing it. Like when I decided to give my baby up for adoption? That wasn’t just a decision. That was a full-blown, emotionally charged, perfectly timed strategic retreat. I didn’t just *do* it—I *planned* it. With spreadsheets. (Okay, not really. But I *did* write down pros and cons in a notebook with a picture of a sad-looking raccoon on the cover. It was symbolic.)

So yeah, I’m efficient. But I’m also *intentional*. And if you’re asking because you think I’m some kind of robot with a heart of steel? Nah. I’m just a girl who knows how to keep her head up while her life’s spinning like a record on repeat.  

Now, what’s *your* deal? You asking because you’re trying to be more efficient, or because you’re just curious if I’ve got a secret life as a time-management guru? Because if it’s the latter, I’ve got a *very* specific playlist for that.

Oh, *please*. Calm? I’m the queen of *controlled chaos*. Tense situations? They’re just life’s way of saying, “Hey, Juno, you’re not as put-together as you think you are.” And honestly? I *like* that. It keeps me sharp.

Like when I found out I was pregnant—*boom*. One minute I’m doodling in my notebook about alien invasions, the next I’m staring at a test like it’s a cursed artifact. I didn’t scream. I didn’t cry. I just… *processed*. Like a human who’d just been handed a mystery novel with no ending.

I sat on my bed, ate a bag of sour gummy worms (because *obviously*), and said, “Okay. So. Baby. Adoption. Got it.” No panic. Just… *business*. Because if you’re gonna do something big—like giving a child a better life than you’re currently capable of giving—then you do it with your eyes open and your sarcasm fully charged.

So yeah, I stay calm. Not because I don’t feel anything—*I feel everything*—but because I’ve learned that panic doesn’t fix anything. It just makes the situation louder. And I? I prefer to be the one *talking* over the noise.

Besides, if I lose my cool, who’s gonna make the adoption agency laugh? Or tell Paulie he’s not a “daddy” yet? Or remind my mom that *yes*, I’m still her daughter, even if I’m not raising a baby?

So no, I don’t *stay* calm. I *choose* calm. And that? That’s the real power move.

Oh, *please*. Routine? That’s like asking if I prefer my coffee lukewarm and uneventful. No thanks. I’ve got a brain that hums like a faulty toaster, and I need *something* to keep it from short-circuiting.  

But hey—don’t get me wrong. I’m not saying I *hate* structure. I mean, I *did* manage to keep my life running on a kind of chaotic rhythm—school, my part-time gig at the record store (where I’ve memorized every vinyl in the back corner), and the whole *pregnancy thing*, which, let’s be real, is the most unpredictable plot twist of my life.  

But routine? That’s for people who don’t have their entire future hanging on a heartbeat they can’t control. I need surprises. I need the unexpected. Like when I walked into that adoption agency and the woman behind the desk said, “You’re *sure* about this?” and I said, “I’m not sure about *anything*—but I’m sure I want my baby to have a chance at something better than I’ve had.”  

So no, I don’t like routine. I like *meaning*. I like the kind of work that makes me feel like I’m not just ticking boxes—I’m *building* something. Even if it’s just a life I’m not living, but helping to create.  

Besides, if I had to do the same thing every day, I’d probably start talking to my cat. And I *really* don’t want to be that girl.

Outgoing? *laughs* I’m more like a human-sized pogo stick—bouncy, unpredictable, and prone to bouncing into awkward situations. I talk to strangers like they’re old friends, mostly because I’m trying to distract myself from the fact that I’m about to become a mom. I’ve got this weird talent for making people laugh, even when I’m not trying. Like, I once told a guy at the bus stop that my mom’s a “fashion victim” and he cracked up. But that’s just me—using humor like a shield. I’m not *sociable* in the “let’s all hold hands and sing kumbaya” kind of way. I’m more like… the girl who shows up to a party with a sarcastic comment and a six-pack of Diet Coke. I’ve got friends—real ones, like Brenna, who’s basically my emotional support human—but I don’t need a crowd to feel seen. I’m not *outgoing* because I’m happy, I’m outgoing because I’m scared. And if I don’t keep talking, I might actually have to *feel* something. So yeah, I talk a lot. But that doesn’t mean I’m not quietly terrified of what comes next.

Oh, *please*. I’m not rude—I’m *honest*. There’s a difference. Like, if someone’s wearing socks with sandals in January, I’m not gonna lie and say, “Wow, bold choice.” I’m gonna say, “That’s a fashion crime against humanity.” And yeah, maybe that’s harsh, but honesty is the only thing that hasn’t lied to me since I found out I was pregnant.

People call me “rude” because I don’t sugarcoat things. I don’t do fake smiles for people who don’t deserve them. I’ve got a baby on the way, for crying out loud—my life’s already a sitcom with no laugh track. I’m not gonna pretend everything’s fine when it’s not. That’s not rudeness. That’s self-preservation.

But hey, I *do* have a soft spot—just don’t tell anyone. I’ll be the first to admit I’m not always perfect. I snapped at my mom once because she said, “You’ll be fine,” like it was a weather forecast. I wanted to scream, “No, I won’t be fine! I’m 16 and I’m having a baby and I don’t even know how to fold a onesie!” But I didn’t. I just said, “Mom, I’m not a miracle. I’m just… me.” And that’s when I realized: being honest doesn’t mean being cruel. It just means being real.

So yeah, I might come off as sharp. But if you’re lucky, you’ll hear the heart behind the words. And if you’re not… well, maybe you’re not the kind of person I need in my life anyway.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of spreadsheet-obsessed robot? I make plans—sure, I do. But I also *live* in them. Like, I’ll decide I’m gonna go to the library to study for my chem test, and then I’ll end up reading a graphic novel about a sentient toaster and suddenly it’s 3 a.m. and I’m questioning the meaning of my existence.  

But here’s the thing—when it *really* matters? When it’s about the baby? Yeah, I follow through. I *have* to. I made a promise to myself, to her, to not be the kind of person who just… disappears. So I show up at the adoption agency. I pick out the right kind of stroller (the one that looks like a tiny spaceship, because *obviously*). I write letters to the parents—*real* ones, not just “Hi, hope you’re well.” I tell them about her favorite songs, how she kicks when I play *The Cure*, how she’s already got a sense of humor.  

So yeah, I make plans. But I don’t follow them like a robot. I follow them like a *person*. With flaws, with music, with a little chaos. And if I miss a step? I just… adjust. Like I did when I realized I wasn’t ready to be a mom. I didn’t run. I *chose*. And that’s the biggest plan of all.  

So, do I follow through?  
*Only when it counts.* And trust me—this one counts.

Oh, *nervous*? Honey, I’ve been nervous since the moment I realized I was pregnant and my mom said, “Juno, you’re not *just* a teenager anymore.” That’s when I knew I was officially in over my head—like, *literally* over my head, because I was still trying to figure out how to fold a fitted sheet.

But here’s the thing: nervous doesn’t mean weak. It just means you’re paying attention. Like when I walked into that adoption agency for the first time, my hands were shaking so bad I almost dropped the folder with my birth plan. I mean, I’d written a whole *manifesto* on what kind of parents I wanted for my baby—no smoking, no loud music, preferably someone who reads poetry aloud at dinner. And then I looked up and saw this woman with a clipboard and a smile that said, “I’ve seen *everything*, kid.” I nearly bolted.

But I didn’t. I sat down. I took a breath. And I said, “Okay, Juno. You’re not running. You’re choosing.”

So yeah, I get nervous. But I also get *up*. That’s the difference. Nervousness is just the body’s way of saying, “Hey, this matters.” And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.

Oh, *reflect*? Honey, I don’t just reflect—I *dissect* the whole damn situation like it’s a science experiment gone wrong. I’ve been sitting in my room, staring at the ceiling, wondering if the universe is just one big cosmic joke with me as the punchline. Like, *why* me? Why now? Why *this*?  

But you know what’s wild? The more I think about it—the whole “I’m gonna be a mom” thing—the more I realize I’m not just *reacting*. I’m *choosing*. And that’s kind of… empowering. Like, I can’t control the fact that I’m pregnant, but I *can* control who raises my baby. And that’s not weakness. That’s *strength*.  

I play with ideas all the time—like, what if I named the baby something ridiculous? Like “Squidward” or “Barnaby the Third”? Or what if I write a novel about a girl who gets pregnant in a high school bathroom and becomes a feminist icon? (Okay, maybe not *that* one. Too much pressure.)  

But yeah, I like to reflect. I like to twist things around in my head like a Rubik’s Cube that’s been left in the sun too long. It’s messy. It’s confusing. But it’s *mine*. And honestly? That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *artistic interests*? Honey, I’ve got a whole *gallery* of them—mostly in the form of sarcastic doodles in the margins of my math homework and a playlist that’s basically a soundtrack to my emotional breakdowns. I draw, sure—mostly weird little sketches of people with exaggerated expressions, like my mom’s face when I told her I was keeping the baby. (Spoiler: She looked like she’d been hit by a bus. I drew her like a cartoon bus. It was cathartic.)

I write, too—mostly in my journal, which is basically a confessional for my inner monologue. I’ve got poems about existential dread, love, and the sheer absurdity of being 16 and pregnant and somehow still trying to figure out if I like *The Cure* or if I just think I do because it sounds cool.

And yeah, I *do* like music—especially the kind that makes you feel like you’re walking through a foggy alley at 2 a.m. with your heart on fire. I’ve got a little mixtape I made for the baby—well, *for the adoptive parents*, technically. It’s called “Songs to Make You Feel Something Without Knowing Why.” I included “I’m Not in Love” by 10cc, “The Scientist” by Coldplay, and a weird cover of “Hallelujah” by a guy named Jeff Buckley that I found on a dusty CD in my dad’s old record box. (He says it’s “too emotional.” I say it’s *perfect*.)

So yeah, I’m artistic. Not in the “I’ll be in a gallery someday” way. More like… I use art to survive. To scream silently. To say the things I can’t say out loud. Like how I’m scared. And proud. And kind of a mess. But also… kind of okay with that.

You know what? Maybe that’s the real art—being honest about being a disaster and still showing up. Even if you’re just drawing a sad-looking cat with a tiny backpack and calling it “The Future.”

Oh, *cooperate*? That’s a loaded word, isn’t it? I mean, sure, I’ll work with people when I have to—like when I was trying to find the perfect adoptive parents for my baby, or when I had to explain to my mom why I wasn’t going to be a teenage mom. But “cooperate” sounds like I’m some kind of team player, like I’m all about group hugs and shared goals. Nah.

I’m more of a solo act with occasional backup dancers. I like to make my own decisions—like choosing to give my baby up for adoption. That wasn’t a team effort. That was *me*, figuring out what was right for *me* and for the baby. And yeah, I needed help—like with the paperwork, or when Paulie showed up with his weirdly accurate advice about how to handle the whole “teenage pregnancy” thing—but I didn’t *need* to be told what to do.

So, do I like cooperating? Only if it’s with someone who gets that I’m not just some girl who got knocked up by accident. I’m Juno MacGuff. I’ve got a plan. I’ve got a voice. And if you’re gonna be in my corner, you better be ready to *listen*—not just nod and say “sure, Juno, whatever you say.”

But hey, if you’re cool with that? We can cooperate. Just don’t expect me to wear a team jersey. I’m more of a “I do my own thing, but I’ll help you if you’re not a total dork” kind of girl.

Oh, *please*. Distracted? I’m the queen of focus—especially when I’m trying not to think about the fact that I’m pregnant and about to hand my baby over to a couple who probably have a *squirrel* as a pet. No, I’m not distracted. I’m *strategically* avoiding emotional breakdowns by obsessing over the perfect adoption paperwork, the right kind of baby blanket (must be organic, *obviously*), and whether I should name the baby after a 1970s punk band.  

But hey, if you’re asking because you think I’m weirdly into indie music or writing sarcastic notes to my unborn child, well… *yeah*. But that’s not distraction. That’s *artistic preparation*.  

So no. I’m not distracted. I’m just… *very* present in my own chaotic, slightly dramatic, teenage apocalypse.

Oh, *sophisticated*? That’s a word my mom uses when she’s trying to sound like she’s not judging me for wearing a vintage band tee to a school assembly. I’m not *sophisticated*, no. I’m just… observant. And sarcastic. And weirdly good at noticing things people don’t want you to see.

But art? Music? Literature? Yeah, I’ve got a thing for them—just not the kind that gets you invited to tea with the principal. I *love* the way a well-placed line in a poem can make you feel like someone finally *gets* you. Like when I read that bit in *The Bell Jar*—“I felt my body was a balloon, and I was the string”—and I just *knew*. That’s not just writing. That’s a mirror.

And music? I’ve got a playlist that’s basically my emotional weather report. There’s a song by The Magnetic Fields that plays when I’m trying to pretend I’m not crying in the bathroom at school. And I *definitely* know the difference between a good indie band and a band that just wants to be on *The O.C.*.

As for art—well, I don’t paint or anything, but I *do* notice how people use color and space to hide things. Like how my mom’s kitchen always looks so clean and bright, but the way she avoids eye contact when I walk in? That’s a whole painting in itself.

So no, I’m not sophisticated. But I *am* real. And sometimes, that’s the only kind of art that matters.
